Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The domesticated pigeon as a model for avian genetics and diversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Remarkably little is known about the number and types of genetic mutations that control differences within and among species. This project takes advantage of the diversity among the 350+ breeds of domestic pigeon - many of which show spectacular diversity in color, feather, and skeletal traits - to identify the genes that control variation in this species. Experimental crosses between dissimilar pigeon breeds will be used to determine the number and chromosome location of genes controlling interesting traits. Additionally, the genomes of many different breeds will be surveyed to find the specific mutations that control variation. Importantly, many of the traits that vary among pigeon breeds also vary among wild species of birds and other animals; thus, new insights gleaned from pigeons will yield a better general understanding of animal diversity.

The pigeon is already an important model organism in biology and medicine, and this project will potentially expand other research programs by providing new tools for genetic analyses. The educational plan of this project will also have local, national, and global impacts. A centerpiece of this plan is a new computer-based virtual pigeon breeder game that will be installed on the Utah Genetic Science Learning Center's highly successful website. These and other new educational materials will be targeted at a diverse community and broad age range, promote critical thinking and self-directed learning, and key components of this plan will be accessible via the Internet to reach millions of people worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In The Origin of Species, Charles Darwin repeatedly calls attention to the spectacular diversity of domestic pigeon breeds as a model for how animals change over time. Different pigeon breeds have vastly different anatomical and behavioral traits, yet they all belong to the same species. Over the course of this grant, we took advantage of pigeon diversity to solve longstanding and fundamental problems about the DNA-level changes that drive evolutionary variation. As a result of our efforts over just a few years, we have discovered aspects of biology from pigeons that Darwin never could have imagined, including how changes to genes can influence tissue identity (e.g., how decisions between skin with scales or feathers are made in the embryo), and how hybridization between species can transfer advantageous traits from one species to another. Pigeons are easily bred in the lab and their embryos are accessible, so we were able to determine the impact of genetic changes on embryonic development in the egg. Importantly, the mutations and their effects that we discovered are not only important to pigeon biology, but they are also fundamental to vertebrate development in general, including human development and disease. These and other successes have built a foundation to pursue more ambitious goals, including determining the genetic basis of complex variation in animal behaviors, an exciting but largely unexplored frontier in vertebrate genetics. During the project period, our research led to 12 publications that reported our original findings, contributed new computational tools so that other researchers can conduct similar studies on other organisms, and reviewed various aspects of vertebrate genetics and development.

Beyond our research accomplishments, the project directly helped to train three postdoctoral fellows, two Ph.D. students, and 15 undergraduate researchers. Our work created new resources such as genome sequences for continuing our pigeon research well into future, and that also will enable others to use genetic approaches for studies of avian biology. In addition, this award resulted in highly impactful educational and outreach activities. In collaboration with the Genetic Science Learning Center (www.learn.genetics.utah.edu), we developed the Pigeonetics video game and associated materials to teach basic concepts in Mendelian genetics. These materials are accessed by hundreds of thousands of users from nearly every country in the world. The game allows users to learn genetics in a fun context and to drill down into some of the original molecular genetics findings from our own research driven by this CAREER award. The game and materials were modified and expanded into a hands-on classroom activity for even wider distribution and utility: https://teach.genetics.utah.edu/content/pigeons/. Our work also inspired educational content from other providers such as the New York Times: https://learning.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/06/darwins-pigeons-learning-about-evolution-from-bird-traits/. These online and classroom educational materials will have a lasting, global impact beyond the project period. Finally, we partnered with the Natural History Museum of Utah on a museum exhibit that highlighted our research and the broader role of pigeons in the history of evolutionary biology. The exhibit was visited by tens of thousands of museum patrons, who had the chance to see one of Darwin?s own pigeon specimens and play the Pigeonetics game at museum kiosks.
